code_quality.details: CRITICAL: eval() still present in search endpoint — remote code execution vulnerability. Two dead functions (unusedHelper, anotherDeadFunction) and two unused formatters (formatTodo, formatTodos) in routes/todo.js. Multiple console.log statements left in production code. Good use of parameterized queries elsewhere and proper HTTP status codes. Swagger jsdoc integration is well done. Has .env.example.

documentation.details: README is basic but functional — has setup instructions, endpoint list, and data structure example. Swagger annotations are thorough and well-structured with full request/response schemas. Missing badges, Docker instructions, and CI/CD documentation.

teams.summary: The eval() vulnerability is the biggest issue — it must be fixed immediately. Clean up the dead code and console.logs. The Swagger docs are a strong point.
tips: CRITICAL: eval() in search endpoint is a remote code execution vulnerability — replace with proper filtering using parameterized queries like the other endpoints
Remove dead functions (unusedHelper, anotherDeadFunction, formatTodo, formatTodos) — they add noise and hurt maintainability
Add try/catch blocks to route handlers for proper error handling

code_quality.details: The /debug endpoint exposes SECRET_KEY and API_KEY with zero protection — no environment check, no auth. Duplicate GET /:id route defined twice in todo.js. Commented-out toObj function at bottom of file. todo.db committed to repo. Good: eval() removed from search, helpers extracted to separate file, Swagger annotations, SonarCloud + CodeQL integration.

documentation.details: README is minimal — just 'a todo api' with npm commands and SonarCloud badges. No endpoint documentation, no env vars, no Docker instructions. Swagger annotations in routes are good and cover all endpoints with descriptions.

teams.summary: Good progress on fixing eval and extracting helpers, but the unprotected /debug endpoint is a serious security issue. Clean up the duplicate route and committed database file.
tips: Remove or protect the /debug endpoint — it exposes environment variables and secrets with no guard
Remove the duplicate GET /:id route and the commented-out toObj function
Update your README with real setup instructions, API docs, and badges — the Swagger work deserves to be showcased

code_quality.details: Good improvements: eval() removed, helmet added for security headers, global error handler, health endpoint, clean require.main guard for server start. However, .env file is committed to the repo (exposing DB_PASSWORD). No try/catch in route handlers. No Swagger or API documentation endpoint.

documentation.details: README is essentially empty — just 'a todo api' with npm install/start. No endpoint docs, no env vars, no setup instructions, no badges. No Swagger or OpenAPI. No .env.example (but actual .env is committed, which is worse).

teams.summary: Solid security improvements with helmet and eval removal, but the committed .env file undermines that work. Documentation needs serious attention.
tips: Move secrets to environment variables (.env) — never commit credentials. Remove .env from repo and add it to .gitignore
Add a .env.example file so others know which env vars are needed
Add Swagger/OpenAPI docs — Express can use swagger-jsdoc + swagger-ui-express

code_quality.details: Clean, well-organized code. eval() removed. /debug endpoint exists but gated behind NODE_ENV !== 'production'. Search uses parameterized queries. Good separation with build.js (esbuild bundling). knip for dead code detection. release-please for versioning. CHANGELOG maintained. formatTodo/formatTodos are somewhat redundant but intentionally used for API output normalization. Console.logs in routes.

documentation.details: Excellent README with badges (coverage, license, Node.js version), prerequisites, install/run/test commands, full API reference with request/response examples for every endpoint. swagger.json provides OpenAPI spec. Missing only Docker instructions and env vars documentation.

teams.summary: One of the strongest repos. Clean code, good CI tooling (knip, release-please, CodeQL), and thorough documentation. The /debug endpoint could be fully removed.
tips: Consider removing the /debug endpoint entirely rather than gating it — even gated, it's a risk if NODE_ENV is misconfigured
Add .env.example file so others know which env vars are needed
Name your PRs with conventional commit format (feat: xxx, fix: xxx) — squash merges use the PR title as the commit message

code_quality.details: Clean and minimal code. eval() removed. No /debug endpoint. Proper parameterized queries. search/all route placed correctly. However: no error handling (no try/catch anywhere), no health endpoint, no input validation beyond title check. Console.log in root endpoint. Prettierrc and eslint configured which is good.

documentation.details: README is the default template — 'a todo api' with npm install/start. No endpoint docs, no env vars, no Docker instructions, no badges. No Swagger or API documentation. No .env.example.

teams.summary: Code is clean but minimal — the bare minimum was done. No documentation effort at all. Needs error handling and API docs.
tips: Update your README with real setup instructions, API docs, and badges
Add Swagger/OpenAPI docs — Express can use swagger-jsdoc + swagger-ui-express
Add try/catch blocks and a global error handler for production readiness

code_quality.details: Excellent code quality. ES modules throughout. eval() removed. /debug endpoint properly gated to development only. Clean route handlers with consistent return statements. Health endpoint. Swagger via @scalar (modern alternative). .env.example provided. compose.yml for Docker. esbuild config for builds. vitest for testing. SonarCloud + Trivy integrations. Separate CI and CD workflows. No dead code.

documentation.details: Outstanding README with table of contents, prerequisites, getting started guide, environment variables table, running instructions, test commands, Docker usage (pull/build/run), complete API reference with all endpoints documented including request/response formats, and CI/CD pipeline description. Swagger UI at /api-docs. Badges for CI, CD, coverage, Node.js, Express, license.

teams.summary: Top-tier repo. Clean modern code (ESM, vitest, @scalar), comprehensive documentation, proper security practices, and full CI/CD pipeline. A model for the class.
tips: Consider adding input validation (Zod or similar) for request bodies beyond the title check
The /debug endpoint could be removed entirely for maximum security — even gated, it's a potential risk
Add a .env.example documentation for the compose.yml setup

code_quality.details: Exemplary code quality. Zod validation schemas for all inputs (create, update, pagination, search) with proper error responses. Helmet for security headers. Morgan for logging. Rate limiting with configurable window/max. CORS properly configured. Global error handler with production/development message distinction. 404 catch-all. Health endpoint with uptime. No eval. No /debug endpoint. Every route wrapped in try/catch with next(err). .env.example with comprehensive variables. release-please for versioning. CHANGELOG maintained. pnpm for package management.

documentation.details: Excellent README with badges (CI, SonarCloud, coverage, Docker), stack overview, detailed setup with prerequisites and commands, full environment variables table, Docker instructions, available commands table, API endpoints table, and deployment environments. Swagger annotations are incredibly detailed with multiple examples per endpoint, edge cases documented, and French descriptions. .env.example is thorough.

teams.summary: The best repo in the class. Production-grade code with input validation, security middleware, rate limiting, and comprehensive error handling. Documentation is exceptional. This is what professional code looks like.
tips: Consider adding request ID tracking for easier log correlation in production
The search endpoint uses /todos/search instead of /todos/search/all — minor deviation from the original spec but arguably cleaner
Name your PRs with conventional commit format (feat: xxx, fix: xxx) — squash merges use the PR title as the commit message

code_quality.details: CRITICAL: eval() still present in search endpoint. /debug endpoint exposes process.env (all environment variables) with zero protection. On the positive side: Swagger is set up, .env.example exists, SonarCloud integration, health endpoint, Docker + docker-compose files.

documentation.details: README is the default template — 'a todo api' with npm install/start. No real documentation. However, Swagger annotations exist in routes covering all endpoints with basic schemas. docs/swagger.js exists for swagger config.

teams.summary: Two critical security issues remain (eval + unprotected /debug exposing all env vars). The infrastructure work (Docker, CI, SonarCloud) is good but the code itself needs urgent fixes.
tips: CRITICAL: eval() in search endpoint is a remote code execution vulnerability — replace with proper filtering
Remove or protect the /debug endpoint — it exposes environment variables and secrets
Move secrets to environment variables (.env) — never commit credentials or hardcode defaults
